    Extract, Join & Add data

    spata-v2-extract-add-and-join-data.Rmd

    The framework in which SPATA2 operates invites you to extract data from the spata-object in order to do your own analysis apart from what SPATA2 currently offers. In order to do that you can make use of a variety of get*()- and joinWith*()-functions.

    # load packages
library(SPATA2)
library(tidyverse)

# load object
spata_obj <- loadSpataObject("data/spata-obj-gbm275.RDS")

    1. Basic extracting functions

    The following code introduces basic get-functions in order to obtain data from your spata-object.

    # the essential data.frame
getSpataDf(spata_obj)
    ## # A tibble: 3,734 x 2
##    barcodes           sample
##    <chr>              <chr> 
##  1 AAACAAGTATCTCCCA-1 T275  
##  2 AAACACCAATAACTGC-1 T275  
##  3 AAACAGAGCGACTCCT-1 T275  
##  4 AAACAGCTTTCAGAAG-1 T275  
##  5 AAACAGGGTCTATATT-1 T275  
##  6 AAACAGTGTTCCTGGG-1 T275  
##  7 AAACATTTCCCGGATT-1 T275  
##  8 AAACCGGGTAGGTACC-1 T275  
##  9 AAACCGTTCGTCCAGG-1 T275  
## 10 AAACCTAAGCAGCCGG-1 T275  
## # ... with 3,724 more rows
    # dimensional reduction data
getUmapDf(spata_obj)
    ## # A tibble: 3,734 x 4
##    barcodes           sample  umap1  umap2
##    <chr>              <chr>   <dbl>  <dbl>
##  1 AAACAAGTATCTCCCA-1 T275    2.45  -2.25 
##  2 AAACACCAATAACTGC-1 T275    6.60  -1.35 
##  3 AAACAGAGCGACTCCT-1 T275   -6.14   3.86 
##  4 AAACAGCTTTCAGAAG-1 T275    0.426  2.06 
##  5 AAACAGGGTCTATATT-1 T275    3.28   1.17 
##  6 AAACAGTGTTCCTGGG-1 T275    4.91  -3.67 
##  7 AAACATTTCCCGGATT-1 T275    4.13  -3.28 
##  8 AAACCGGGTAGGTACC-1 T275    1.14   2.37 
##  9 AAACCGTTCGTCCAGG-1 T275    4.61  -0.952
## 10 AAACCTAAGCAGCCGG-1 T275    5.87  -3.03 
## # ... with 3,724 more rows
    # barcode spot coordinates
getCoordsDf(spata_obj)
    ## # A tibble: 3,734 x 4
##    barcodes           sample     x     y
##    <chr>              <chr>  <dbl> <dbl>
##  1 AAACAAGTATCTCCCA-1 T275    435.  374.
##  2 AAACACCAATAACTGC-1 T275    132.  429.
##  3 AAACAGAGCGACTCCT-1 T275    407.  145.

##  5 AAACAGGGTCTATATT-1 T275    110.  353.

##  7 AAACATTTCCCGGATT-1 T275    416.  443.

##  9 AAACCGTTCGTCCAGG-1 T275    216.  385.
## 10 AAACCTAAGCAGCCGG-1 T275    365.  468.
## # ... with 3,724 more rows
    # feature data
getFeatureDf(spata_obj)

    Type SPATA::get in your console to skim SPATA2â€™s namespace and to see all available get*()-functions.

    The joinWith-family

    As spatial transcriptomics analysis centers around the spatial expression of certain features it makes sense to start your spata-exclusive analysis by extracting the spatial coordinates of the sample of interest via getCoordinates().

    # 1. get a data.frame that contains barcodes variables
coords_df <- getCoordsDf(spata_obj)

# output
coords_df
    ## # A tibble: 3,734 x 4
##    barcodes           sample     x     y
##    <chr>              <chr>  <dbl> <dbl>
##  1 AAACAAGTATCTCCCA-1 T275    435.  374.
##  2 AAACACCAATAACTGC-1 T275    132.  429.
##  3 AAACAGAGCGACTCCT-1 T275    407.  145.
##  4 AAACAGCTTTCAGAAG-1 T275     96   327 
##  5 AAACAGGGTCTATATT-1 T275    110.  353.
##  6 AAACAGTGTTCCTGGG-1 T275    219.  518.
##  7 AAACATTTCCCGGATT-1 T275    416.  443.
##  8 AAACCGGGTAGGTACC-1 T275    165.  321.
##  9 AAACCGTTCGTCCAGG-1 T275    216.  385.
## 10 AAACCTAAGCAGCCGG-1 T275    365.  468.
## # ... with 3,724 more rows

    The coordinates themself arenâ€™t particularly revealing which is why one needs to combine the coordinates of a barcode-spot with the respective information. As mentioned previously, SPATA2 is oriented towards the tidy-data approach which is demonstrated in particular by the joinWith*()-functions. Itâ€™s members leverage dplyr::left_join() to itâ€™s fullest by making it ridiculously easy to extract your data in a barcode-spot related fashion. In order to get a detailed report about what every member of that family does run ?joinWith in your R-console. Although they might differ slightly in names and arguments they all follow the same concept. They

    1.) take a data.frame containing the character-variables â€˜barcodesâ€™ and â€˜sampleâ€™.

    2.) extract the specified gene-, gene-set or feature information. (and perform normalization or spatial smoothing if specified)

    3.) return the data.frame with the specified variables included.

    # 2. join this data.frame with additional information
joined_df <- 
  joinWith(object = spata_obj, 
           spata_df = coords_df,
           gene_sets = "HM_HYPOXIA", # expression values of the gene set Hallmark-Hypoxia
           features = "seurat_clusters", # cluster belonging
           verbose = FALSE)

# output 
joined_df
    ## # A tibble: 3,734 x 6
##    barcodes           sample     x     y seurat_clusters HM_HYPOXIA
##    <chr>              <chr>  <dbl> <dbl> <fct>                <dbl>
##  1 AAACAAGTATCTCCCA-1 T275    435.  374. 0                    0.197
##  2 AAACACCAATAACTGC-1 T275    132.  429. 2                    0.206
##  3 AAACAGAGCGACTCCT-1 T275    407.  145. 1                    0.249
##  4 AAACAGCTTTCAGAAG-1 T275     96   327  3                    0.282
##  5 AAACAGGGTCTATATT-1 T275    110.  353. 5                    0.228
##  6 AAACAGTGTTCCTGGG-1 T275    219.  518. 0                    0.219
##  7 AAACATTTCCCGGATT-1 T275    416.  443. 0                    0.216
##  8 AAACCGGGTAGGTACC-1 T275    165.  321. 3                    0.255
##  9 AAACCGTTCGTCCAGG-1 T275    216.  385. 2                    0.198
## 10 AAACCTAAGCAGCCGG-1 T275    365.  468. 6                    0.235
## # ... with 3,724 more rows

    It does not matter how many barcodes of a sample the particular data.frame contains. The specified variables are extracted and joined by their â€˜barcodesâ€™-variable whereby the barcodes inside the coords_df-data.frame are determining. The joinWith-family does not extend nor reduce the number of barcode-spots (or observations for that matter) but simply adds the desired information to the data.frame in form of additional variables using the barcodes as unique identifiers for every value.

    The number of variables of these data.frames can be expanded infinitely as long as there is a character-variable called â€™barcodesâ€™. Just specify it again as input for argument spata_df and tell joinWith() which information-variables it is supposed to add.

    3. Add results to the spata-object

    There is a variety of functions that allow to add data (e.g.Â new features, expression matrices, etc.) to your spata-object.

    3.1 Features

    Letâ€™s assume your analysis resulted in a new clustering variable that you would like to integrate into the SPATA2-workflow. The data.frame might now look somewhat like this:

    ## # A tibble: 3,734 x 3
##    barcodes           sample new_cluster_variable
##    <chr>              <chr>  <fct>               
##  1 AAACAAGTATCTCCCA-1 T275   Cluster_5           
##  2 AAACACCAATAACTGC-1 T275   Cluster_1           
##  3 AAACAGAGCGACTCCT-1 T275   Cluster_3           
##  4 AAACAGCTTTCAGAAG-1 T275   Cluster_7           
##  5 AAACAGGGTCTATATT-1 T275   Cluster_7           
##  6 AAACAGTGTTCCTGGG-1 T275   Cluster_3           
##  7 AAACATTTCCCGGATT-1 T275   Cluster_3           
##  8 AAACCGGGTAGGTACC-1 T275   Cluster_7           
##  9 AAACCGTTCGTCCAGG-1 T275   Cluster_5           
## 10 AAACCTAAGCAGCCGG-1 T275   Cluster_6           
## # ... with 3,724 more rows

    It carries a new calculated feature that gives additional information about every barcode-spot. Whatever your analysis results in, as long as it is a variable in a data.frame that additionally contains the barcodes of your spata-object in a â€˜barcodesâ€™-variable you can add that variable to your spata-object to make it universally accessible for all SPATA2-functions. Use addFeatures()for that matter.

    # initial features in slot @fdata
getFeatureNames(spata_obj)
    ##            numeric            integer            numeric            numeric 
##   "nCount_Spatial" "nFeature_Spatial"       "percent.mt"       "percent.RB" 
##             factor          character             factor             factor 
##  "seurat_clusters"     "segmentation"      "Leiden_UMAP"          "cluster" 
##            logical 
##             "keep"
    # add the feature
spata_obj <- addFeatures(object = spata_obj,
                         feature_names = "new_cluster_variable",
                         feature_df = example_df
                         )

# new features in slot @fdata
getFeatureNames(spata_obj)
    ##                numeric                integer                numeric 
##       "nCount_Spatial"     "nFeature_Spatial"           "percent.mt" 
##                numeric                 factor              character 
##           "percent.RB"      "seurat_clusters"         "segmentation" 
##                 factor                 factor                logical 
##          "Leiden_UMAP"              "cluster"                 "keep" 
##                 factor 
## "new_cluster_variable"

    3.2 Miscellaneous

    Type SPATA::add in your console to skim SPATA2â€™s namespace and to see all available add*()-functions. The main difference between add*()-functions and set*()-functions is this one: add*()-functions refer to datatypes that can coexist in infinite numbers such as feature variables (addFeatures()) or expression matrices that were processed and normalized in different ways (addExpressionMatrix()). set*()-functions refer to datatypes that can exist only one time. There can be only one count matrix (setCountMatrix()) and only one feature data.frame (setFeatureDf()). set*()-functions overwrite the data slots content without asking for further permission. Use them with caution.
